tdBB0ZTkb5dKEXoULx1JUA.text: To clarify, I grew up in Brazil and love the whole concept of the Churrascaria - we have been to several Fogo de Chao establishments, and have enjoyed them.  We brought some great friends here shortly after they opened. I make picanha at home, and thought that maybe it would be fun to contrast mine with the "experts." Well, this one time made me really look awesome...  I get it that the place is new, and has a lot to learn. We will most likely go back after a year or so, to let them iron out the major issues. I personally think that there are two really pressing issues that NEED to improve, but may not be able to for business reasons (and that's why I'm not a restaurateur, but instead a gourmand...)  One - the meat seems to be "roasted" over gas and not wood fired / natural charcoal. I didn't see their kitchens, but the meat just didn't have the classic "gaucho" taste to it - it was good quality beef (and pork, lamb, etc...), but the flavor was just bland. Because it was early in their opening period, I think there were also not many meat servers, or "gauchos," so the meat was able to get a little cold as they meandered around the tables - hopefully this will improve as the establishment becomes more settled and popular. The big draw for a "churrascaria" is it's meat experience, so this aspect has GOT to be spot on and of exceptional quality: fresh, high quality meats, prepared to perfect standards. The selection was a lot of lamb and pork, rather than prime grass fed Brazilian beef, too - could also use some improved traditional selections like real linguica (pork sausages) and chicken hearts / livers, if the clientele will go for it.  Two - Everything else was just "average." The other times I have gone to a Fogo de Chao, I've had to actually prepare myself: I didn't eat the entire day before going, and I also had to make a mental note to not assault the amazing "salad bar" or gorge on delicious warm "pao de queijo" (cheese bread, made with tapioca flour) - these adjuncts have always made it easy for churrascarias to distract customers from the more expensive, high quality grass fed Brazilian beef. Unfortunately, this establishment had fairly modest and average offerings in these areas. Cheese bread was cold and hard, and the salad bar was what I'd expect from a T.G.I. Friday's. They mentioned "Feijoada" on their menu, and that is dangerous for any place that has Brazilians in the mix - feijoada is the traditional black beans and rice, with pork and other meats - it's the absolute paragon of the Brazilian culinary experience, and I wanted some. Only, there was none. Apparently we would have to wait until 3pm or something like that. Unfortunately, at $50 a head for average food, and with $13 caipirinhas that had too much ice, we just could not sit around and wait.  We will come back after about a year to give It another go, but it's really trying to define itself. I'm happy that this legendary franchise has opened here in town and is trying to elevate things a notch above what a Texas de Brasil is aiming for, but they do have to bring it. There ARE quite a few Brazilians in town, and we love good churrasco - it can't be phoned in.  Oh, one last critique - we had only one quick pass on the Picanha, despite talking to a gentleman we believed was the manager. Picanha is why we make the reservation - it has to come around, and more than once or twice to keep us making reservations.  To the proprietors: I hope that business is growing and that things are heating up! My review does not mean that I don't like what you were doing, but rather is a starting point - we support you and WANT you to succeed. If you can grow this establishment into the legendary mold of its predecessors, I believe nothing but great success will follow. I truly wish you excellent fortune, and will be back to enjoy seeing how you've grown! Obrigado, e eu espero que voces tenham todo o sucesso do mundo apos alguns ajustes.

gY5fX7SCoVaIzjA16cSewQ.text: I came to Fogo de Chao with a group of friends. We made a reservation and had to wait an hour still after that. I kind of expected that, but we went to the bar area and no efforts were made to tell us that our reservations were ready in that area. I get that it was crowded, but I had to push my way to the hostess stand to find out that they had been calling for our reservation.   The absolute worst part was that I was barely getting any meat. I immediately flipped my medallion when I sat down. It was another 15 minutes until the first person came by with meat that was on our menu. Then, the meat that came by was slow and sparing. We later encountered another 25+ minute stretch where there was NO MEAT coming by. At other Brazilian steakhouses I've been to, I was turning away cuts of meat I didn't want constantly and as soon as I got a few I'd have to turn the medallion over - at this Fogo I literally never flipped my medallion over to the red side. Then I left hungry because I had been there for an hour waiting, then another couple hours actually at the table, and I was tired.   There were a few positive points - the lamb, parmesan chicken, chicken wing and the bottom sirloin were extremely good. I didn't enjoy every cut of meat I had but I didn't expect to. I know the waitress and and meat servers were extremely busy so I don't begrudge them, and when they came by to ask if I would like a specific cut of meat I managed to get it. I'd give this place another chance if someone asked me to come out since it seems to be mostly organizational issues, but I would never pick it myself when there are other Brazilian steakhouses around.

qoXPC02V4lbTTrC2DIPM_w.text: The bad: We we're constantly ignored by wait staff, the only meat that came to our table without us directly requesting were the cheaper sirloin cuts.  When requesting filet, sausage, or beef ribs.. we would have to ask 3 times before it would come to us. In general most of the meat was overcooked and at most Brazilian steakhouse they ask how you'd like it done. At the end of the night the wait staff didn't have a bill for our table and we tried to tell them what we had but the bill took over 30 min to get.  After we paid on our way out we we're stopped and said they needed to review our bill.  At that point we kept walking.. will not be back.   The good:. Beef ribs, pork ribs, Chicken salad, potato salad, bacon.. we're all delicious, bar drinks were made well.

wTRos8E2YkUgXF1IUA7mPQ.text: Apparently they don't take walk-ins when they have a lot of reservations on the books. Turned away a party of four and the restaurant was maybe a quarter full and not busy. Refused to seat us, stating that they were sold out. We asked if we could sit at the bar which was completely empty, and they told us yes but we could not get the rodizio. Honestly, it could've been handled a lot better. I've been in the restaurant business for years and I've never turned someone away even with reservations on the books when my restaurant was only a quarter full. And we're talking a large restaurant. Just in poor taste. No worries, we hit up Texas de Brazil and had a great dinner.

vJ772ipPkGiHNRJSVjEQGQ.text: I have eaten at many Brazilian steak houses. I will say that this is the best one so far. Staff was very friendly and personable. The cuts of Meats were perfect. Loved the ribeye and bacon wrapped sirloin. The salad bar was OK. Nothing too special. But, let's be honest, we are there for the skewers of meat. I even had dessert which is something I never do. Looking forward to going back.

Db3zwJufvA-pP4FShralQQ.text: I highly recommend this restaurant for delicious Brazilian food. Having lived in Brazil myself, my expectations were very elevated. The food was on point, and there was everything I could have wished for, from the salad and feijoada bar, to the pao de queijo (cheese bread), caramelized bananas, and finally to the excellent cuts of meat grilled to perfection. The high point of the experience was the professional wait staff. Extremely kind, attentive and helpful. Give it a try!

aJtdn-bEZWFWJwiQISd8hA.text: Typical Brazillian steak house, great cuts of meat, not too much variety, no duck.  Salad bar was little on the skimpy side, service was good, meats were good. Don't expect to compare to NYC with their extended salad bar that includes fresh sushi.  But remember Pittsburgh is $48 per person verses $75 per head in NYC. Overall good value, real food.
